This is, without a doubt, one of my favorite Columbo episodes ever. The acting is very well done, the music is very catchy, the script and dialogue are very interesting and well-written, and the ending I thought was great.
Sadly, it was a great deal more predictable than most of the episodes, which may be why it really didn't hit the heights it very well could have. It was also often a little hard to really understand other characters' motivations.

Leland follows the story of Leland P. Fitzgerald (Ryan Gosling), a disaffected teenager who has apparently murdered a severely retarded peer, the brother of popular high school student and athlete, Laurie Ludman (Rachel McAdams.) This is essentially a story about finding what you love, and then losing it. It's a story about what your life could look like when passion takes over. It's also a film of moral ambiguity and a fascinating exploration of mental illness

A woman who hates cats (Alice Krige) and her son (Brian Krause) have moved into a small town, and must deal with a mean cat. The cat, left to fend for itself when its owner moves away, has gone feral and taken to stalking victims and drinking from one and burying its dead.
